skill.name: file-search
skill.description: Modern file and content search using fd, ripgrep (rg), and fzf. Triggers on: fd, ripgrep, rg, find files, search code, fzf, fuzzy find, search codebase.
skill.summary: Modern file and content search using fd, ripgrep (rg), and fzf. Triggers on: fd, ripgrep, rg, find f...
skill.author: 0xDarkMatter

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown files. No executable code, no MCP definitions, no network calls, no file system access, and no command execution. The skill provides informational content about using fd, ripgrep, and fzf command-line tools.

content.value_statement: Finding files and searching code can be slow with standard tools. This skill provides quick reference for fd, ripgrep, and fzf to search and filter files instantly. Use these tools to locate code, navigate projects, and filter search results with minimal effort.
actual_capabilities: Find files by name, extension, type, and pattern using fd
Search file contents with ripgrep including regex and multiline patterns
Filter and select results interactively with fzf
Combine tools for powerful workflows like search-then-select
Preview files before opening with bat integration
Batch operations on multiple selected files
limitations: Requires fd, ripgrep, and fzf to be installed separately
Documentation only - does not execute searches directly
No built-in file editing or modification capabilities
Interactive features depend on terminal support

use_cases.title: Locate code patterns
use_cases.description: Find function definitions, TODO comments, and specific code patterns across large codebases quickly

use_cases.title: Search config files
use_cases.description: Find configuration files by name or content, filter by modification time and file size

use_cases.title: Analyze project structure
use_cases.description: Identify large files, count TODO items, detect unused imports, and review git changes

prompt_templates.title: Content search
prompt_templates.description: Search for error messages in log files with context
prompt_templates.prompt: Search for 'error' in log files showing 3 lines of context

prompt_templates.title: Interactive selection
prompt_templates.prompt: Use fzf to show files with preview using bat for quick viewing

prompt_templates.title: Combined workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Find TypeScript files containing 'async' and open them in the editor

best_practices: Use type flags like -t f and -t d instead of glob patterns for faster searches
Narrow the search path to relevant directories to improve performance
Combine fd for finding, rg for searching, and fzf for interactive filtering
anti_patterns: Using find instead of fd (fd is faster and ignores gitignore by default)
Searching without type filters when you know the file extension
Running searches on the entire filesystem instead of the project directory

faq.question: What tools do I need to install?
faq.answer: Install fd, ripgrep, and fzf using your package manager. On macOS: brew install fd ripgrep fzf

faq.question: How is fd different from the find command?
faq.answer: fd is faster, ignores gitignore by default, has better default sorting, and uses intuitive syntax

faq.question: Can this skill search in gitignored files?
faq.answer: fd and ripgrep respect gitignore by default. Use --no-ignore flag to include ignored files

faq.question: Is my data safe with these tools?
faq.answer: Yes. These tools only read files locally. No data is sent to external servers or stored anywhere

faq.question: Why are my searches slow?
faq.answer: Searches are slow when searching too broad a path, not using type filters, or matching complex regex patterns

faq.question: How does this compare to IDE search?
faq.answer: These CLI tools are faster for large codebases, work in any terminal, and can be combined into powerful workflows
